awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Understanding Context: Propagation and Effectiveness of the Concept Warehouse in Mechanical Engineering at Five Diverse Institutions and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
An increase in the number and diversity of graduates in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields is important for the nation's competitiveness. Concept-based active learning strategies have been shown to improve students' academic performance and increase the number who choose to stay in STEM programs. However, scientific proof that these strategies are effective is not enough to make sure instructors use them in courses. It is also necessary to understand and find ways to get instructors to adopt proven practices. In this project new online concept-based materials for mechanical engineering courses in Statics and Dynamics will be developed. The project team will study why instructors decide to use the materials, and how factors at five different types of institutions affect these decisions. The project will help to show how circumstances at different institutions affect both instructor adoption as well as student learning and motivation. It will help inform ways to support widespread use of the evidence-based instructional practice. Thus, it will also help more students stay in and graduate from engineering programs.

The goal of this project is to increase the adoption of concept-based active learning throughout undergraduate engineering programs. It builds upon the project team's previous success in developing the web-based Concept Warehouse instructional resource for chemical engineering. The resource contains hundreds of short questions to engage students in concept-oriented thinking, to assess their conceptual knowledge, and to provide extensive concept-based active learning tools. The project will expand Concept Warehouse to include content in mechanical engineering. Participating institutions include research-intensive and Hispanic-serving institutions, as well as a two-year college. A systems approach will be used to examine how elements of the educational context, such as size and departmental culture, influence instructor uptake and the resulting student learning. A mixed-methods research design will include the use of data analytics, instructor interviews, student focus groups, observations, classroom video, and pre/post concept inventory scores. The research plan will also address ways in which student backgrounds and demographics (e.g., underrepresented minorities; first-generation status) interact with institutional settings to affect student learning and engagement. Workshops and faculty community building activities will be used to promote propagation of the enhanced evidence-based instructional practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding Context is a collaborative project among several institutions: Allan Hancock College (community college), California Polytechnic University San Luis Obispo (comprehensive public university), Bucknell University (small, private university), Tufts University (medium, private research university), University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez (a Hispanic-serving university), and Oregon State University and University of Washington (large public research universities). 

The project successfully propagated an instructional tool, the Concept Warehouse, to Mechanical Engineering instruction. Since the start of the grant, over 800 ConcepTests for Mechanics have been created (356, 460, 42 for Statics, Dynamics, and Mechanics of Materials, respectively).  To date, 70 instructors from dozens of institutions have deployed over 2,000 questions, leading to nearly 4,000 unique students using these questions, and over 56,000 answers submitted.  Several Inquiry-Based Learning Activities and Active Learning Modules, providing a useful resource for engineering faculty, have also been created.  Project faculty used these resources in a California Education Learning Lab intersegmental (community college-and university) grant project, “The Mechanics of Inclusion, and Inclusivity in Mechanics.”

Research has improved understanding of the technology adoption process and of faculty development more generally, and led to new ways to support engineering instruction across diverse institutions.  Three research threads were pursued.  First, the propagation of educational technology among faculty in diverse settings has been characterized.  Faculty adoption of technology, and how it is implemented in particular situations, is not only dependent on individual faculty preferences, but on the institutional/academic environment, the ease with which technology integrates with current academic systems, and students’ response to changes in instruction.  Second, this project expanded understanding of how students conceptualize engineering work.  By analyzing students’ written explanations of their answers to the ConcepTests, researchers learned how they approach new material and the nature of their understanding of mechanics and engineering knowledge.  It was discovered that a significant number of students who select the correct answer do not provide an adequate explanation, suggesting that instructors should pay attention to student reasoning.  Third, the collection of student reasoning samples has facilitated research using Large Language Models; this research will allow artificial intelligence assisted tools to provide faculty information about student thinking so that they can adapt classroom instruction to provide corrective measures earlier in the learning process to better meet learners’ needs. 

The project increased its impact on the field by reporting research and offering interactive workshops at professional conferences (e.g., ASEE, AIChE), as well onsite at colleges of engineering across the country.  In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the project supported over 120 faculty in transitioning to online teaching with two extensive workshops in Summer 2020.  After the pandemic, a successful workshop was held at UPR Mayaguez to further expand the development and deployment of the Concept Warehouse.  

The project developed an online cohort of Action Research Scholars, producing several spin-off research projects on student learning. Communities of Practice – cohorts of faculty who taught Statics and Dynamics and using the Concept Warehouse – were developed, with positive impact on faculty learning and sharing new technology and methods of instruction.  The Communities of Practice helped drive the development and refinement of ConcepTests in the Concept Warehouse, as well as increased and strengthened the network of the dedicated mechanics instructors. 

The Concept Warehouse was enhanced by the introduction of fundamental engineering mechanics courses (Statics and Dynamics).  Faculty who adopt ConcepTests are helping students gain a deeper conceptual understanding of mechanics early in their academic careers.  Researchers have learned and will continue to learn about the adoption and use of technology to aid both faculty and students.
